paragraphs.name: be07
paragraphs.text: I keep lots of notebooks. One for ideas and stream of consciousness and one for each project or thing I’m working on. So I have one for a music project, one for a book I’m writing, and one for each startup I’m working on or advising.
Sometimes people get tripped up because they have no idea what they’ll put in their notebooks. Other times they don’t want to ruin something as beautiful as a Moleskine with their chicken scratch.

paragraphs.name: 3e18
paragraphs.text: Ha ha.. Very nice.. I kinda go through a similar dilemma of picking a right notebook when I have plenty. Or even be a lil scared of spoiling it with any useless rumbles. Now I kinda relate to it n find it funny. :D maybe that’s the purpose of having a notebook in the first place. And also not restricting to one book is in itself so liberating which eventually might instigate me to just start emoting on any God damn paper right away!

paragraphs.name: 4c5e
paragraphs.text: With respect to Srinivas, I think you’ll get more out of your notebook if you go a little crazy. Actually, not a little. You should fear being committed to a mental institution lest someone finds your notebook (that’s why you never fill in the “This Notebook Belongs To _____” label). Here’s my advice:

paragraphs.name: 451d
paragraphs.text: Very nice guide! I love notebooks too, but, since I seem to have an obsession for compartmentalising things, I have one for my daily life (to-do lists, meetings, scribbling), one for deeper thoughts and feelings (“dear diary” kind of stuff), one for film reviews and countless for story ideas. I have problems. 😸

a4947a19bb65.title: Yep. Anything that helps us remove “good” and “bad” as adjectives to describe our own notebooks is…

paragraphs.text: Yep. Anything that helps us remove “good” and “bad” as adjectives to describe our own notebooks is a good thing. Personal journals can’t be good or bad — just ours!

paragraphs.name: 47e1
paragraphs.text: I love notebooks. I have tried those digital ones for my phone like evernote, but there is nothing like a real paper filled notebook. I actually have custom made collage notebooks. Hahaaha. I used to be a rapper way back when, ever since then i have always kept real notebooks.

85a8faa7e1c0.title: Hmm. To my mind, you’ve already “really used them:” They’ve hosted zillions of your wacky ideas so…

paragraphs.name: 2c64
paragraphs.text: Hmm. To my mind, you’ve already “really used them:” They’ve hosted zillions of your wacky ideas so that your brain could make space for new ones. That’s a journal’s raison d’être, non? In case that answer isn’t satisfying, though: Recycle ‘em!

This was awesome. I journal a lot/take notes and sometimes I feel like I have to write something worthy of the notebook itself(cause it looks so good). Maybe I should get a real ugly one? Yeah. I’ma do that.

a7301f4cc197.title: 100% agree that the pen is all part of the ritual.

paragraphs.text: 100% agree that the pen is all part of the ritual. For me, it has to be the Pilot Precise v5 RT. It writes smooth and rich.

20b26ef1a5cc.title: Love your words of honesty in the article and your notebooks!

paragraphs.text: Love your words of honesty in the article and your notebooks! Very fresh perspective on writing, Journaling, creating, etc. You’ve given me inspiration to go out and get more notebooks for my vehicle, back porch, office etc. instead of looking and wasting time and energy for the one my ADDled brain left on top of the fridge, or even in the fridge.

paragraphs.name: 34b4
paragraphs.text: Thanks for the shoutout Jessica Guzik. One thing is clear, your handwriting and illustrations are more beautiful than mine :). And completely agree with putting in the stupid stuff too. I’d say 90% of what I write in my notebooks is unusable stream of consciousness nonsense. But one sentence often plants the seed for an article or idea that turns…

edf33f5495fb.title: Yes, I’ve struggled with this problem, when something is too beautiful or too cool to mess up.

paragraphs.name: c21f
paragraphs.text: Yes, I’ve struggled with this problem, when something is too beautiful or too cool to mess up. Some writers recommend making a big mess in the notebook to break the… ink, so to speak. One advantage of making your own notebooks is you know how good or bad they are and you can get rid of any reverence REAL FAST.

7d7478966031.title: Do it! One of my favorite scraps to write on?

paragraphs.name: 89fc
paragraphs.text: Do it! One of my favorite scraps to write on? Receipts. They’re already time-stamped and pre-loaded with an itemized description of what you did that day (e.g., bought beef jerky, Big Red gum, and tampons)
